title: How do I sell my house if cosigner filed bankruptcy
question: I'm primary on mortgage loan,an uncle co signed loan and filed bankruptcy. Now my loan is in bankruptcy and I'm trying to sell my house and was told by realtor it needs to be out of bankruptcy. How do go about getting it out of bankruptcy and is it legal for it to have gotten in bankruptcy without any notification to me?
answers:
Your uncle signed bankruptcy documents under penalty of perjury. He was required to disclose in those documents all assets in which he has any legal or equitable interest. He was not required to contact you prior to filing the bankruptcy case. Assuming the bankruptcy case closes without the Trustee administering (selling) your uncle's equity in the house, the title of the house will re-vest (go back to) the owners as if there had been no bankruptcy.

There are just too many factual possibilities for a complete answer to your situation. Here is what I recommend you do ASAP:

Find a bankruptcy attorney in your area who has a good reputation (Avvo is as good a place to find one as any).

Make an appointment to meet with the attorney (hopefully a free consultation).

Take your bankruptcy Notice, and the bankruptcy documents (Petition and schedules) if it is convenient for your to get a copies, and take a copy of all the loan documents with you to meet with an attorney.

Ask the attorney if there is a problem with the house title to the house, and if so, what needs to be done.

Do not be afraid to get second opinion if you still have questions.

Good Luck

That the mortgage was listed creditor really shouldn't matter, but it is almost certain that your uncle is also on the title, otherwise he couldn't be a co-signer on a Deed of Trust. If he is on title, he is a co-owner and the real property is an asset in the bankruptcy case. If your uncle couldn't claim the equity that he technically owns as exempt, then the trustee in his bankruptcy may sell your property.

If that happens, you are entitled to half of the net proceeds, but probably can't stop the sale unless you can "buy out" the trustee in your uncle's case.

If you uncle was NOT on the title, then the property is not part of the bankruptcy (I'm intentionally not discussing any issue over a recent transfer of the title back into your name; that is more complicated than what can be posted here). Many title companies will still not guarantee title until the bankruptcy case is closed. If you are the sole owner and there are no transfer issues, there is not reason why you can't sell the property at any time.

Get your title, a copy of your uncle's bankruptcy documents (in particular the Schedules and Statement of Financial Affairs) and go see an experience bankruptcy attorney. They can tell you what you are allowed to do. Again, you may get title companies or realtors that won't process this until the bankruptcy is closed; they don't usually do anything if there is a bankruptcy connected to the property or the loans while the case is pending.

There are several issues that have not been addressed in your inquiry. Is your Uncle on title? Does he claim an interest in the property or did he just co-sign on the loan? Was the property listed in Uncle's bankruptcy case? Was Uncle represented by an attorney? Most realtors do not have sufficient accurate knowledge about bankruptcy to be advising their clients about these issues. I urge you to speak with a bankruptcy attorney to assist you.

For your purposes it is more important to know who is on title. Your house is not in your uncle's bankruptcy estate unless he is on title. Your uncle's debt is in his bankruptcy case. He can discharge his liability. If he is not on title his bankruptcy should not interfere with you ability to sell the house.

Consult a bankruptcy attorney about what steps you can take to minimize your loss and see if it's possible to keep the property out of the bankruptcy estate. Not sure what you mean by "my loan is in bankruptcy." Either your loan is in default or it's not. You are the primary borrower and should know whether you're current on your payments.

A Chapter 7 bankruptcy can take as little as 4 months to complete, while a Chapter 13 bankruptcy can take 5 years or more. Realtors shouldn't be giving legal advice, you can sell property while one of the owners is in bankruptcy but you will need court permission. Does uncle still have an ownership interest in the property? Did uncle claim and receive an exemption for any ownership interest he may have. The uncle's interest may belong to the bankruptcy court now. It isn't possible to give accurate answers to questions without a lot more details, More info at the link below
